articles.headline: Same-Sex Marriage Activists Look to Law
articles.snippet: Efforts by gays and lesbians to overcome the legal obstacles faced by same-sex couples, notably the Defense of Marriage Act, may best be fought in courtrooms.
articles.abstract: Efforts by gays and lesbians to overcome the legal obstacles faced by same-sex couples, notably the Defense of Marriage Act, may best be fought in courtrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: While President Obama’s support for same-sex marriage is symbolic, his words have little power to erase the long list of extra costs and legal hurdles that same-sex couples face. For a more realistic chance at change, gay couples are probably better off looking to the courts.

articles.headline: Iran Presses for Official to Be Next Leader of Shiites
articles.snippet: Ayatollah Mahmoud Hashemi Shahroudi would extend Iran’s influence over the Iraqi people and Shiite Muslims everywhere if he were to succeed Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani.
articles.abstract: Ayatollah Mahmoud Hashemi Shahroudi would extend Iran’s influence over the Iraqi people and Shiite Muslims everywhere if he were to succeed Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq — As the top spiritual leader in the Shiite Muslim world, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani has instructed his followers on what to eat and how to wash, how to marry and to bury their dead. As a temporal guide, he has championed Iraqi democracy, insisting on direct elections from the earliest days of the occupation, and warned against Iranian-style clerical rule.

articles.headline: As Dewey Collapses, Partners and Retirees Face Big Financial Losses
articles.snippet: All past and present partners could lose pensions, and recent partners will probably lose investments in the firm and could be forced to return salaries as the firm closes.
articles.abstract: All past and present partners could lose pensions, and recent partners will probably lose investments in the firm and could be forced to return salaries as the firm closes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the law partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf, losing their jobs may be the least of their worries.

articles.headline: Loss Stains JPMorgan’s Chief, One of Banking’s Top Risk Managers
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss disclosed late Thursday is a rare misstep by the bank’s chief, Jamie Dimon, who prides himself on having his fingers on the pulse of his 270,000-employee company. It suggests his vaunted confidence edged to...
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss disclosed late Thursday is a rare misstep by the bank’s chief, Jamie Dimon, who prides himself on having his fingers on the pulse of his 270,000-employee company. It suggests his vaunted confidence edged toward hubris.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days before revelations of JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss rocked Wall Street, the company’s always-confident chief executive, Jamie Dimon, was his usual exuberant self.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: In North Carolina, Beliefs Clash on Marriage Law
articles.snippet: Many people were surprised that the vote on same-sex marriage in North Carolina was so decisive, but the state’s political inconsistencies include a long tradition of social conservatism.
articles.abstract: Many people were surprised that the vote on same-sex marriage in North Carolina was so decisive, but the state’s political inconsistencies include a long tradition of social conservatism.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — North Carolina is as good a place as any and possibly better than most to explore the often contradictory sentiments at the heart of the same-sex marriage debate.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Sought Loophole on Risky Trading
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase fought for the ability for banks to make big bets in their portfolios, including some of the types of trading that led to the $2 billion loss now rocking the bank.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase fought for the ability for banks to make big bets in their portfolios, including some of the types of trading that led to the $2 billion loss now rocking the bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after lawmakers finished work on the nation’s new financial regulatory law, a team of JPMorgan Chase lobbyists descended on Washington. Their goal was to obtain special breaks that would allow banks to make big bets in their portfolios, including some of the types of trading that led to the $2 billion loss now rocking the bank.

articles.headline: Romney Tells Evangelicals Their Values Are His, Too
articles.snippet: Speaking at Liberty University, Mitt Romney sought to quell concerns among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of Christian values and faith in public life.
articles.abstract: Speaking at Liberty University, Mitt Romney sought to quell concerns among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of Christian values and faith in public life.
articles.lead_paragraph: LYNCHBURG, Va. — Mitt Romney traveled to Liberty University, the spiritual heart of the conservative movement, on Saturday, seeking to quell concerns about him among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life.

articles.headline: A Generation Hobbled by the Soaring Cost of College
articles.snippet: Nearly everyone pursuing a bachelor’s degree is borrowing money, and as prices soar, a college degree often comes with an unprecedented financial burden.
articles.abstract: Nearly everyone pursuing a bachelor’s degree is borrowing money, and as prices soar, a college degree often comes with an unprecedented financial burden.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADA, Ohio — Kelsey Griffith graduates on Sunday from Ohio Northern University. To start paying off her $120,000 in student debt, she is already working two restaurant jobs and will soon give up her apartment here to live with her parents. Her mother, who co-signed on the loans, is taking out a life insurance policy on her daughter.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: At JPMorgan, the Ghost of Dinner Parties Past
articles.snippet: The $2 billion trading loss disclosed last week by JPMorgan Chase shows how the tables have turned on the bank and its chief executive, an industry point man against tighter regulation.
articles.abstract: The $2 billion trading loss disclosed last week by JPMorgan Chase shows how the tables have turned on the bank and its chief executive, an industry point man against tighter regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT goes around comes around. Sometimes it happens sooner than you’d think.

articles.headline: The Education of Mark Zuckerberg
articles.snippet: Facebook’s founder and 28-year-old C.E.O. will soon face the unfamiliar landscape of running a public company, monitored by a merciless stock market.
articles.abstract: Facebook’s founder and 28-year-old C.E.O. will soon face the unfamiliar landscape of running a public company, monitored by a merciless stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg is ready for his close-up.
articles.byline: By Evelyn M. Rusli, Nicole Perlroth and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Writer’s Cramp: In the E-Reader Era, a Book a Year Is Slacking
articles.snippet: Some authors, like the novelist James Patterson, are producing 12 or more books a year to satisfy readers who are increasingly used to on-demand entertainment.
articles.abstract: Some authors, like the novelist James Patterson, are producing 12 or more books a year to satisfy readers who are increasingly used to on-demand entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, it was a schedule as predictable as a calendar: novelists who specialized in mysteries, thrillers and romance would write one book a year, output that was considered not only sufficient, but productive.

articles.headline: For Tea Party, Focus Turns to Senate and Shake-Up
articles.snippet: Tea Party-backed Republican candidates for the Senate are looking to infuse the upper chamber with the deep-seated conservatism that is present in the House.
articles.abstract: Tea Party-backed Republican candidates for the Senate are looking to infuse the upper chamber with the deep-seated conservatism that is present in the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The primary victory of a Tea Party-blessed candidate in Indiana illustrates how closely Republican hopes for a majority in the Senate are tied to candidates who pledge to infuse the chamber with the deep-seated conservatism that has been the hallmark of the House since the Republicans gained control in 2010.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Echoing Out of Texas, Chinese Voice of Dissent for Religious Freedom
articles.snippet: Bob Fu, a Chinese-born pastor who started the dissident group ChinaAid, was instrumental in calling attention to the plight of the activist Chen Guangcheng.
articles.abstract: Bob Fu, a Chinese-born pastor who started the dissident group ChinaAid, was instrumental in calling attention to the plight of the activist Chen Guangcheng.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex. — When the Chinese activist Chen Guangcheng stole the show at an emergency Congressional hearing this month by calling into the chamber during a live television broadcast, few people noticed who was holding the cellphone.

articles.headline: U.S. May Scrap Costly Efforts to Train Iraqi Police
articles.snippet: The State Department could jettison a multibillion-dollar training effort by the end of 2012 that has emerged as the latest high-profile example of America’s waning influence in the country.
articles.abstract: The State Department could jettison a multibillion-dollar training effort by the end of 2012 that has emerged as the latest high-profile example of America’s waning influence in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In the face of spiraling costs and Iraqi officials who say they never wanted it in the first place, the State Department has slashed — and may jettison entirely by the end of the year — a multibillion-dollar police training program that was to have been the centerpiece of a hugely expanded civilian mission here.

articles.headline: More Talks Set as Leaders in Greece Seek Unity Coalition
articles.snippet: The chances of Greek politicians’ forming a unity government all but evaporated on Sunday, but President Karolos Papoulias said he would keep trying.
articles.abstract: The chances of Greek politicians’ forming a unity government all but evaporated on Sunday, but President Karolos Papoulias said he would keep trying.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The chances of Greek politicians’ forming a unity government all but evaporated on Sunday, hurtling the country toward new elections and throwing further doubt on whether it could remain a member of the euro zone and avoid defaulting on its debts.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Facebook’s Purchases May Hint at Its Future
articles.snippet: Because Facebook tends to be tight-lipped about its plans, the company’s string of acquisitions may reveal a lot about the course it is charting.
articles.abstract: Because Facebook tends to be tight-lipped about its plans, the company’s string of acquisitions may reveal a lot about the course it is charting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook’s billion-dollar purchase of Instagram made a lot of noise — so much noise that few people noticed when the company snapped up two more start-ups just a few days later.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Chase Executive Resigns in Trading Debacle
articles.snippet: Ina R. Drew, JPMorgan Chase’s chief investment officer and a three-decade employee there, and two traders who worked for her will leave the company.
articles.abstract: Ina R. Drew, JPMorgan Chase’s chief investment officer and a three-decade employee there, and two traders who worked for her will leave the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stung by a huge trading loss, JPMorgan Chase will replace three top traders starting Monday, including one of the top women on Wall Street, in an effort to stem the ire that the bank faces from regulators and investors.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: As Talent Flees to Cable, Networks Fight Back
articles.snippet: Broadcast networks are offering shorter seasons and agreeing to air serialized shows uninterrupted by reruns to fight “cable envy” among series creators.
articles.abstract: Broadcast networks are offering shorter seasons and agreeing to air serialized shows uninterrupted by reruns to fight “cable envy” among series creators.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was once the ultimate prize for a creator of drama series on television: a call from one of the broadcast networks during upfront week to say that his or her new project had been selected to fill an hour on the prime-time schedule.

articles.headline: After Obama’s Decision on Marriage, a Call to Pastors
articles.snippet: After President Obama announced his support for gay marriage, he and his team embarked on a quiet campaign to contain the possible damage among religious leaders and voters.
articles.abstract: After President Obama announced his support for gay marriage, he and his team embarked on a quiet campaign to contain the possible damage among religious leaders and voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About two hours after declaring his support for same-sex marriage last week, President Obama gathered eight or so African-American ministers on a conference call to explain himself. He had struggled with the decision, he said, but had come to believe it was the right one.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Rachel L. Swarns

articles.headline: So Eager for Grandchildren, They’re Paying the Egg-Freezing Clinic
articles.snippet: The practice of freezing eggs to enable a pregnancy later on is growing, doctors say, with parents lending emotional and financial support to adult daughters.
articles.abstract: The practice of freezing eggs to enable a pregnancy later on is growing, doctors say, with parents lending emotional and financial support to adult daughters.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Colorado Center for Reproductive Medicine, a popular destination for women hoping to preserve their fertility by freezing their eggs, Dr. William Schoolcraft, the founder and medical director, has started to notice something different: more of the women are arriving with company.

articles.headline: Idahoan’s Unlikely Journey to Life as a Taliban Prisoner
articles.snippet: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who was captured in 2009 and is America’s only known current prisoner of war, saw enlisting in the Army as a way to find a direction, relatives say.
articles.abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who was captured in 2009 and is America’s only known current prisoner of war, saw enlisting in the Army as a way to find a direction, relatives say.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAILEY, Idaho — Off a gravel road in a horse pasture in the crystalline air of the Northern Rockies, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl grew up skiing, fencing and dancing the role of the Nutcracker in the nearby Sun Valley Ballet School — on the surface, at least, an unlikely recruit for the United States Army.
